content: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant' (CNN) — Days after national Republicans launched a new campaign to broaden the party's outreach, former upstart presidential candidate Mike Huckabee says the GOP is at risk of becoming "irrelevant as the Whigs." In an interview with the California newspaper The Visalia Times-Delta, Huckabee said the GOP would only further decline in influence should it alienate social conservatives — largely considered the most energetic and loyal faction of the party. "Throw the social conservatives the pro-life, pro-family people overboard and the Republican party will be as irrelevant as the Whigs," he said in reference to the American political party that largely disbanded in the mid 1800s. "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. Full article at ... >>>http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/08/huckabee-warns-gop-could-become-irrelevant/
reply: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant' (CNN) — Days after national Republicans launched a new campaign to broaden the party's outreach, former upstart presidential candidate Mike Huckabee says the GOP is at risk of becoming "irrelevant as the Whigs." In an interview with the California newspaper The Visalia Times-Delta, Huckabee said the GOP would only further decline in influence should it alienate social conservatives — largely considered the most energetic and loyal faction of the party. "Throw the social conservatives the pro-life, pro-family people overboard and the Republican party will be as irrelevant as the Whigs," he said in reference to the American political party that largely disbanded in the mid 1800s. "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. Full article at ... >>>http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/08/huckabee-warns-gop-could-become-irrelevant/
title: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant'

content: LOL, who cares. The Democrats can be irrelevant as well. They are over-reaching with their liberal policies and most americans do not like his policies. Yea Obama's points are up but his POLICIES are NOT. I will stay independent and vote on the best candidate, not on a party and those that are beholden to a party are the ones being fooled. Be it the Dems or Repubs. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin
reply: LOL, who cares. The Democrats can be irrelevant as well. They are over-reaching with their liberal policies and most americans do not like his policies. Yea Obama's points are up but his POLICIES are NOT. I will stay independent and vote on the best candidate, not on a party and those that are beholden to a party are the ones being fooled. content: It's comes down to socio-economic issues, national defense, and abortion. Depending on where you stand on these three issues alone, determines where you stand when it comes to choosing political party affiliation. In the grand scheme of things, neither party is "irrelevant" on these issues, whether in or out of power. "The World's Finest"
reply: It's comes down to socio-economic issues, national defense, and abortion. Depending on where you stand on these three issues alone, determines where you stand when it comes to choosing political party affiliation. In the grand scheme of things, neither party is "irrelevant" on these issues, whether in or out of power. "The World's Finest"

They are well down that path already, but it may not be too late to reverse course. There appear to be two factions struggling for control of the party now. One suspects they took a wrong turn and recognizes the need to change course while the other side seems unable to read the road signs and just wants to accelerate down the road to irrelevance.

content: It is sad that the "old, gray haired men" are looked upon with such disdain and contempt. These are the people, women included, who have been around, who have lived through the tough times, who remember when our government deployed troops to fight they let them win instead of stopping at the 38th parallel (look it up), pulling them out of Nam and calling it a win or tie or whatever the hell they did. These folks (yes I'm one of them") are a lot less radical and more thoughtful than you would believe, they are not arrogant enought to have written an autobiography at age 40 or so. Talk to some of them without projecting your bias or contempt and you may just be surprised. A lot of talent and intelligence is being wasted in this country, to the dismay of many. The 60's hippies and the MTV generation may have the bully pulpit, but they still have a lot to learn.

content: Perhaps he is missing the point. A friend of mine who is in Bible school right now made an interesting observation on Facebook this evening, one that fits well into the discussion here. In studying the apostolic sermons in the book of Acts, he noticed that the Apostles always preached Christ, but never once even mentioned Ceasar. Perhaps there is something to that. It is not only the party that lost its way in this unholy marriage between the Republican party machine and the Evangelical movement - the church has, as well. I submit that the governor has allowed his former profession to cloud his political judgment, and is making precisely the recommendation that will plunge his party into deepening obscurity. When will the Evangelicals realize that they have been cynically used by the previous president's political handlers for secular gain and get back to their real duty - preaching the positive message of their Christ?
reply: Perhaps he is missing the point. A friend of mine who is in Bible school right now made an interesting observation on Facebook this evening, one that fits well into the discussion here. title: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant'

content: quote: Originally posted by BPCR45_90: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant' (CNN) — Days after national Republicans launched a new campaign to broaden the party's outreach, former upstart presidential candidate Mike Huckabee says the GOP is at risk of becoming "irrelevant as the Whigs." In an interview with the California newspaper The Visalia Times-Delta, Huckabee said the GOP would only further decline in influence should it alienate social conservatives — largely considered the most energetic and loyal faction of the party. "Throw the social conservatives the pro-life, pro-family people overboard and the Republican party will be as irrelevant as the Whigs," he said in reference to the American political party that largely disbanded in the mid 1800s. "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. Full article at ... >>>http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/08/huckabee-warns-gop-could-become-irrelevant/ It is the intolerant, far-right social conservatives, the religious right, who have done the most to drive the GOP down that path to irrelevance. They are well down that path already, but it may not be too late to reverse course. There appear to be two factions struggling for control of the party now. One suspects they took a wrong turn and recognizes the need to change course while the other side seems unable to read the road signs and just wants to accelerate down the road to irrelevance. "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. That's a very interesting quote! I like it.... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
quote: Originally posted by BPCR45_90: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant' (CNN) — Days after national Republicans launched a new campaign to broaden the party's outreach, former upstart presidential candidate Mike Huckabee says the GOP is at risk of becoming "irrelevant as the Whigs." In an interview with the California newspaper The Visalia Times-Delta, Huckabee said the GOP would only further decline in influence should it alienate social conservatives — largely considered the most energetic and loyal faction of the party. "Throw the social conservatives the pro-life, pro-family people overboard and the Republican party will be as irrelevant as the Whigs," he said in reference to the American political party that largely disbanded in the mid 1800s. "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. Full article at ... >>>http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/08/huckabee-warns-gop-could-become-irrelevant/ It is the intolerant, far-right social conservatives, the religious right, who have done the most to drive the GOP down that path to irrelevance. They are well down that path already, but it may not be too late to reverse course. There appear to be two factions struggling for control of the party now. One suspects they took a wrong turn and recognizes the need to change course while the other side seems unable to read the road signs and just wants to accelerate down the road to irrelevance.
reply: "They'll basically be a party of gray-haired old men sitting around the country club puffing cigars, sipping brandy and wondering whatever happened to the country. That will be the end of the party," he said in the interview published Thursday. That's a very interesting quote! I like it.... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
title: Huckabee warns GOP could become 'irrelevant'

content: It is sad that the "old, gray haired men" are looked upon with such disdain and contempt. These are the people, women included, who have been around, who have lived through the tough times, who remember when our government deployed troops to fight they let them win instead of stopping at the 38th parallel (look it up), pulling them out of Nam and calling it a win or tie or whatever the hell they did. These folks (yes I'm one of them") are a lot less radical and more thoughtful than you would believe, they are not arrogant enought to have written an autobiography at age 40 or so. Talk to some of them without projecting your bias or contempt and you may just be surprised. A lot of talent and intelligence is being wasted in this country, to the dismay of many. The 60's hippies and the MTV generation may have the bully pulpit, but they still have a lot to learn.
reply: It is sad that the "old, gray haired men" are looked upon with such disdain and contempt. These folks (yes I'm one of them") are a lot less radical and more thoughtful than you would believe, they are not arrogant enought to have written an autobiography at age 40 or so. content: Perhaps he is missing the point. A friend of mine who is in Bible school right now made an interesting observation on Facebook this evening, one that fits well into the discussion here. In studying the apostolic sermons in the book of Acts, he noticed that the Apostles always preached Christ, but never once even mentioned Ceasar. Perhaps there is something to that. It is not only the party that lost its way in this unholy marriage between the Republican party machine and the Evangelical movement - the church has, as well. I submit that the governor has allowed his former profession to cloud his political judgment, and is making precisely the recommendation that will plunge his party into deepening obscurity. When will the Evangelicals realize that they have been cynically used by the previous president's political handlers for secular gain and get back to their real duty - preaching the positive message of their Christ?
reply: Perhaps he is missing the point. A friend of mine who is in Bible school right now made an interesting observation on Facebook this evening, one that fits well into the discussion here. In studying the apostolic sermons in the book of Acts, he noticed that the Apostles always preached Christ, but never once even mentioned Ceasar. Perhaps there is something to that. I submit that the governor has allowed his former profession to cloud his political judgment, and is making precisely the recommendation that will plunge his party into deepening obscurity.
